icer.name: ACM International Computing Education Research Conference (ICER)

chi.name: ACM SIGCHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI)

sigcse.name: ACM Technical Symposium on Computer Science Education (SIGCSE), Research Track

sigcsex.name: ACM Technical Symposium on Computer Science Education (SIGCSE), Experience Report Track

icse.name: ACM/IEEE International Conference on Software Engineering (ICSE)

seip.name: ACM/IEEE International Conference on Software Engineering (ICSE), Software Engineering in Practice

seet.name: International Conference on Software Engineering (ICSE), Software Engineering Education and Training Track

uist.name: ACM Symposium on User Interface Software and Technology (UIST)

vlhcc.name: IEEE Symposium on Visual Languages and Human-Centered Computing (VL/HCC)

hcipacm.name: Proceedings of the ACM on Human-Computer Interaction

pubs.title: Critically Conscious Computing: Methods for Secondary Education
pubs.contribution: A book for secondary educators who want to teach CS from critical lens, examining it from technical, sociotechnical, and sociopoitical stance.

pubs.title: Surfacing Equity Issues in Large Computing Courses with Peer-Ranked, Demographically-Labeled Student Feedback
pubs.contribution: Developed and evaluated tool that contextualizes student feedback for teaching teams to identify equity issues.

pubs.title: An Exploratory Study of Sharing Strategic Programming Knowledge
pubs.contribution: Finds that developers can share strategies for programming, but they struggle in choosing a level of detail and understanding the diversity of the potential audience, requiring substantial feedback, but also that developers struggle to give feedback on strategies.

pubs.title: Family as a Third Space for AI Literacies: How Do Children and Parents Learn about AI Together?
pubs.contribution: Finds that parents mediate children's learning by taking on different roles, including mentor, student, collaborator, and tinkerer, and that family learning promotes new framings of consumer devices in homes.

pubs.title: “A key to reducing inequities in like, AI, is by reducing inequities everywhere first”: Emerging Critical Consciousness in a Co-Constructed Secondary CS Classroom
pubs.contribution: Finds that before there is space for critical consciousness about CS, teachers have to navigate issues of trust, positionality, and inequitable systems of education.

pubs.title: The House of Computing: Integrating Counternarratives into Computer Systems Education
pubs.contribution: Teaching computer systems through the lens of sociopolitical and historical choices can open space for student reexamination of technical knowledge and values.

pubs.title: HowToo: A Platform for Sharing, Finding, and Using Programming Strategies
pubs.contribution: Contributes HowToo, a system for encoding strategic programming knowledge as step-by-step procedures for structuring programming tasks. Finds that novice developers found the platform helpful for guiding their work, except when they were rushing toward deadlines.

pubs.title: Domain Experts’ Interpretations of Assessment Bias in a Scaled, Online Computer Science Curriculum
pubs.contribution: Finds systemtic test gender and bias in Code.org's assessments, but barriers to interpreting psychometric results.

pubs.title: How Do Children’s Perceptions of Machine Intelligence Change when Training & Coding Smart Programs?
pubs.contribution: Discovers that children, after building and training small machine learned programs, come to view smart devices as less intelligent, shifting agency from the device to developers.

pubs.title: Falx: Synthesis-Powered Visualization Authoring
pubs.contribution: Contributes a synthesizer-powered visualization tool that allows users to specify examples of how concrete data values should be rendered, and receive one or more data visualizations that transform data accordingly. Finds that users can effectively adopt Falx to create visualizations.

pubs.title: A Theory of Robust API Knowledge
pubs.contribution: Contributes a novel theory of robust API knowledge, including knowledge about the domain that an API models, knowledge of the semantics of API functionality, and knowledge of API usage patterns.

pubs.title: Towards Understanding the Effective Design of Automated Formative Feedback for Programming Assignments
pubs.contribution: Finds that feedback addressing the gap between expected and actual outputs is critical to effective learning and that feedback lacking sufficient detail on these gaps leads to gaming behaviors.

pubs.title: Investigating Item Bias in a CS1 exam with Differential Item Functioning
pubs.contribution: Demonstrates how to conduct a DIF analysis through a case study of a particular large CS1 exam, which revealed some item bias.

pubs.title: Foundations of Information
pubs.contribution: This book covers information, and all of the things that intersect with it: power, politics, oppression, data, knowledge, encoding, metadata; information technology, management, and policy; and the many domains in which information is crucial, including science, social media, automation, health, democracy, and sustainabiity. It serves as the foundation of our survey course on information, INFO 200 Intellectual Foundations of Informatics.

pubs.title: On the Role of Design in K-12 Computing Education
pubs.contribution: Disentangles the role of design in K-12 CS education, finding that design ideas are pervasive in curricula and standards, but conflict program space and problem space design, masking the distinct challenges of problem space design.

pubs.title: It’s Time for More Critical CS Education
pubs.contribution: Argues that CS educators at all levels have the responsibility of the role of computing in injustice.

pubs.title: Learning Machine Learning with Personal Data Helps Stakeholders Ground Advocacy Arguments in Model Mechanics
pubs.contribution: Finds that teaching machine learning by tracing an algorithm with learners' personal data increases the extent to which they can identify bias in self-advocacy arguments.

pubs.title: The Effect of Informing Agency in Self-Directed Online Learning Environments
pubs.contribution: Finds that affording more agency in learning environments may increase motivation, but may not improve learning because of the increased burden on decision-making.

pubs.title: Toward the Development of HCI Pedagogical Content Knowledge
pubs.source: ACM SIGCHI Symposium on HCI Education (EduCHI 2020)
pubs.contribution: Discusses the need for research on HCI educator's pedagogical content knowledge.

pubs.title: Computing Students' Learning Difficulties in HCI Education
pubs.contribution: Investigates the challenges that computing students face in learning HCI, finding challenges in understanding design as distinct from engineering, understanding design methods, finding resources to support design, interpreting feedback, scoping design problems, choosing between alternatives, and designing for diversity.

pubs.title: Scout: Rapid Exploration of Interface Layout Alternatives through High-Level Design Constraints
pubs.contribution: Presents a system to support designers ideation of user interface layouts, allowing designers to provide high-level preferences, obtain a set of layouts that meet those preferences, provide feedback on those preferences, and iteratively converge towards preferred layouts. An evaluation showed that designers who used Scout accelerated ideation and found more diverse designs that designers without it.

pubs.title: Investigating Novices' In Situ Reflections on Their Programming Process
pubs.contribution: Presents evidence that self-regulation during programming is highly variable in practice, and that teaching self-regulation skills to improve programming outcomes may require differentiated instruction based on students self-awareness and existing programming practices.

pubs.title: Explicit Programming Strategies
pubs.contribution: Presents the concept of explicit programming strategies, the idea of encoding manual procedures for solving programming programmers to accelerate software development problem solving. Presents a notation for encoding strategies and evidence that developers using explicit strategies, independent of expertise, were more successful at the design and debugging tasks.

pubs.title: What Distinguishes Great Software Engineers?
pubs.contribution: Via a survey of nearly 2,000 developers, finds that great engineers are distinguished by writing good code, adapting to future business value and costs, being great decision-makers, avoiding making others’ jobs harder, and continuously learning.

pubs.title: Towards Validity for a Formative Assessment for Language-Specific Program Tracing Skills
pubs.source: ACM Koli Calling International Conference on Computing Education Research
pubs.contribution: Contributes theoretical perspectives on how to assess program tracing skills, and how to think about assessment validity.

pubs.title: A Systematic Investigation of Replications in Computing Education Research
pubs.contribution: Analyzed the replication rate and trends in computing education, finding that only about 2% of studies were replicated in the field in the last decade.

pubs.title: A Study Design Design Process
pubs.source: Cambridge Handbook on Computing Education Research (Sally Fincher, Anthony Robin, Eds.)
pubs.contribution: Describes a process for designing studies in the domain of computing education research, though the process is more broadly useful for empirical study design in general.

pubs.title: Learning Outside the Classroom
pubs.source: Cambridge Handbook on Computing Education Research (Sally Fincher, Anthony Robin, Eds.)
pubs.contribution: Surveys the small but growing literature on informal learning of computing and the contexts, technologies, and skills that support it. Identifies a several open questions about how to support informal learning and integrate it with more formal learning.

pubs.title: Tools and Environments
pubs.source: Cambridge Handbook on Computing Education Research (Sally Fincher, Anthony Robin, Eds.)
pubs.contribution: Surveys the role of tools in learning computing, and the genres of tools that researchers have explored, including IDEs, e-books, automated assessment and feedback, and visualization. Identifies a range of open questions.

pubs.title: A Theory of Instruction for Introductory Programming Skills
pubs.contribution: Proposes a theory that identifies four distinct skills that novices learn incrementally: tracing, writing syntax, comprehending reusable abstractions of programming knowledge (templates). Demonstrates that teaching these skills incrementally can result in improved completion rate on practice exercises and decreased error rate and improved understanding of the post-test.

pubs.title: Human-Centered Methods to Boost Productivity
pubs.source: Sadowski C., Zimmermann T. (eds) Rethinking Productivity in Software Engineering. Apress, Berkeley, CA
pubs.contribution: Describes several methods for understanding how to increase developer productivity.

pubs.title: Individual, Team, Organization, and Market: Four Lenses of Productivity
pubs.source: Sadowski C., Zimmermann T. (Eds) Rethinking Productivity in Software Engineering. Apress, Berkeley, CA
pubs.contribution: Discusses several levels of abstraction useful for reasoning about software engineering productivity.

pubs.title: Why Not to Measure Productivity
pubs.source: Sadowski C., Zimmermann T. (eds) Rethinking Productivity in Software Engineering. Apress, Berkeley, CA
pubs.contribution: Presents several arguments for the dangers of measuring software developer productivity.

pubs.title: Teaching Explicit Programming Strategies to Adolescents
pubs.contribution: Attempts to teach explicit strategies for reuse and debugging, finding that adolescents struggle to follow systematic approaches to problem solving.

pubs.title: Teaching Accessibility: A Design Exploration of Faculty Professional Development at Scale
pubs.contribution: Describes and evaluates a vision for teaching higher education CS faculty how to integrate accessibility topics into their classes, discovering many personal and organizational barriers to adoption.

pubs.title: An Item Response Theory Evaluation of a Language-Independent CS1 Knowledge Assessment
pubs.contribution: Evaluates the SCS1 language independent concept inventory, demonstrating how to use IRT to evaluate assessments, and that the SCS1 has several items that may be too hard to be useful.

pubs.title: Informatics Teaching Guide
pubs.contribution: Supports new higher education teachers, including new faculty, guest faculty, doctoral student teachers, and teaching assistants. It uses our undergraduate Informatics program for examples, but is in essence a practical, but also research-informed introduction to teaching in a university.

pubs.title: Scout: Mixed-Initiative Exploration of Design Variations through High-Level Design Constraints
pubs.contribution: Describes early work on a system to support rapid design exploration of user interface layouts.

pubs.title: On Use of Theory in Computing Education Research
pubs.contribution: Argues that our desire to both advance explanatory theory and advance design splits our attention, which prevents us from excelling at both; that our emphasis on applying and refining general theories of learning is done at the expense of domain-specific theories of computer science knowledge; and our use of theory as a critical lens in peer review prevents the publication of designs that may accelerate design progress.

pubs.title: Pedagogical Content Knowledge for Teaching Inclusive Design
pubs.contribution: Through interviews and observations, identifies 11 components of pedagogical content knowledge required to teach inclusive design in HCI education, including strategies for anticipating and addressing resistance to the topic of inclusion, strategies for modeling and scaffolding perspective taking, and strategies for tailoring instruction to students’ prior beliefs and biases.

pubs.title: Experiences of Computer Science Transfer Students
pubs.contribution: Finds that while transfer students in one university were more diverse demographically, the support of the university for transfer student orientation mitigated any social effects of transferring, but did not eliminate gaps in academic performance.

pubs.title: Rewire: Interface Design Assistance from Examples
pubs.contribution: Presents a technique for automatically converting screenshots of imagines into vector representations for use by designers. Demonstrates that designers find the technique accurate enough and superior to replicating user interfaces manually.

pubs.title: Empowering Families Facing English Literacy Challenges to Jointly Engage in Computer Programming
pubs.contribution: Investigates how a programming-by-demonstration programming environment with no English text can facilitate joint-media engagement between children and their parents.

pubs.title: Informal Mentoring of Adolescents about Computing: Relationships, Roles, Qualities, and Impact
pubs.contribution: Investigates the nature of informal computing mentoring relationships amongst students seeking to be the first in their family to attend college. Demonstrates that mentorship occurs even in low-resource settings with little CS expertise, and most often amongst peers and siblings.

pubs.title: An Explicit Strategy to Scaffold Novice Program Tracing
pubs.contribution: Describes and evaluates a simple but powerful strategy for scaffolding the tracing of program execution. With less than 30 minutes of practice, novices in a CS1 course had midterm grades 7% higher.

pubs.title: Who Teaches Accessibility? A Survey of U.S. Computing Faculty
pubs.contribution: Investigates the prevalence of instruction on accessibility among computing and information science faculty. Finds that nearly all HCI faculty teach something about accessibility, that most faculty want to teach it, but don't have the experience, and don't know how it fits into their course content.

pubs.title: Mining the Mind, Minding the Mine: Grand Challenges in Comprehension and Mining
pubs.source: ACM International Conference on Mining Software Repositories
pubs.contribution: Argues that program comprehension and mining software repositories research are mutually relevant in surprising ways.

pubs.title: Modeling Programming Problem Solving Through Interactive Worked Examples
pubs.source: Workshop on Evaluation and Usability of Programming Languages and Tools (PLATEAU)
pubs.contribution: Briefly overviews a vision for programming process worked examples that demonstrate an expert working through a programming problem.

pubs.title: Predicting Abandonment in Online Coding Tutorials
pubs.contribution: Investigates the feasibility of predicting when a learner will abandon a coding tutorial, finding that account activation and help-seeking behavior predict continued learning, while tutorial features indicating struggle predicted abandonment.

pubs.title: Comprehension First: Evaluating a Novel Pedagogy and Tutoring System for Program Tracing in CS1
pubs.contribution: Contributes a new theory of what it means to know a programming language, a novel pedagogy and computer-based tutorial for teaching this knowledge, and evidence that 1) the tutorial promotes significantly higher learning gains over conventional programming language tutorials, and 2) that these gains predict the majority of the variance in CS1 midterm grades.

pubs.title: Barriers Faced by Coding Bootcamp Students
pubs.contribution: Finds that bootcamps can be an alternate path into the software industry for people who missed earlier computing education opportunities, particularly for women, but students face great personal costs and risks, including significant time, money, and effort before, during, and after bootcamps.

pubs.title: Computing Mentorship in a Software Boomtown: Relationships to Adolescent Interest and Beliefs
pubs.contribution: Finds that interest in computing was strongly related to having a mentoring relationship and not to gender or socioeconomic status, that teens with mentors also engaged in significantly more computing education and had more diverse beliefs about peers who engaged in computing education, and that teens who took a class from an instructor who aimed to become students’ teacher-mentor had significantly greater positive changes in interest in computing than those who already had a mentor.

pubs.title: Cross-Disciplinary Perspectives on Collaborations with Software Engineers
pubs.source: International Workshop on Cooperative and Human Aspects of Software Engineering (CHASE)
pubs.contribution: Finds that non-software developers who collaborate with software developers described great software engineers as masters of their own technical domain, open-minded to the input of others, proactively informing everyone, and seeing the big picture of how pieces fit together.

pubs.title: Genie: Input Retargeting on the Web through Command Reverse Engineering
pubs.contribution: Presents Genie, a system to reverse engineer and retarget interactive commands on a website, which allows users to engage with the web via arbitrary input modalities, including speech, keyboard, and command-line input.

pubs.title: A Three-Year Participant Observation of Software Startup Software Evolution
pubs.contribution: Describes an analysis my personal diary reflecting on 9,000 hours of software startup work, presenting nine claims about software engineering work.

pubs.title: General Principles for a Generalized Idea Garden
pubs.source: Journal of Visual Languages and Computing
pubs.contribution: Describes the general architecture for the Idea Garden paradigm and a series of studies that suggest it's effectiveness at unblocking learners' problem solving.

pubs.title: A Pedagogical Analysis of Online Coding Tutorials
pubs.contribution: Using a set of pedagogical principles, evaluates the current state of tutorial instruction, finding that only a few tutorials follow best practices.

pubs.title: User Interface Software and Technology
pubs.contribution: An online, self-published book that surveys the past, present, and future of user interfaces from theoretical, practical, and ethical perspectives.

pubs.title: What is a Programming Language, Really?
pubs.source: ACM Workshop on Workshop on Evaluation and Usability of Programming Languages and Tools (PLATEAU)
pubs.contribution: Reflects on the implications of various definitions of programming languages on research and practice.

pubs.title: AccessComputing Promotes Teaching Accessibility
pubs.contribution: Discusses AccessComputing efforts to implement and disseminate curriculum on accessibility into academia and industry.

pubs.title: The Role of Self-Regulation in Programming Problem Solving Process and Success
pubs.contribution: Finds that while most novices engage in self-regulation to navigate and inform their problem solving efforts, these self-regulation efforts are only effective when accompanied by programming knowledge adequate to succeed at solving a given problem.

pubs.title: The World is Your Test Suite
pubs.source: Perspectives on Data Science for Software Engineering, 1st Edition
pubs.contribution: Discusses the importance of monitoring, bug reporting, and user feedback in verifying requirements.

pubs.title: Programmers are Users Too: Human Centered Methods for Improving Tools for Programming
pubs.contribution: Argues that HCI methods are directly applicable to designing and developing software development tools, and provides an overview of several methods that have been used in research to invent and evaluate new developer tools.

pubs.title: Programming, Problem Solving, and Self-Awareness: Effects of Explicit Guidance
pubs.contribution: Teaching novice programmers the structure of programming problem solving activities and to be aware of which activity they are conducting and whether they are succeeding has a substantial impact on their productivity, self-efficacy, independence, and growth mindset.

pubs.title: The Importance of Computing Education Research
pubs.contribution: Argues for the foundational role of computing education research in computer science departments.

pubs.title: Cooperative Software Development
pubs.contribution: An online, self-published book that covers software engineering fundamentals, but from a human, social, collaborative, and organizational perspective, rather than from a purely technical perspective.

pubs.title: Explaining Visual Changes in Web Interfaces
pubs.contribution: An algorithm and interface that allows web developers to select a before and after state of a web site to see the code that caused the changes.

pubs.title: A Principled Evaluation for a Principled Idea Garden
pubs.contribution: In-context help on programming problem solving helps learners with diverse learning strategies work more independently.

pubs.title: Comparing the Effectiveness of Online Learning Approaches on CS1 Learning Outcomes
pubs.contribution: Mastery learning approaches to teaching programming produce better skills in program tracing than task-free open-ended creative environments.

pubs.title: What Makes a Great Software Engineer?
pubs.contribution: Software engineering expertise is much more about personality, interpersonal skills, and decision-making expertise than about technical knowledge and ability.

pubs.title: From User-Centered Design to Adoption-Centered Design: A Case Study of a Research System Becoming a Product
pubs.contribution: Research prototypes and evidence of their usability and usefulness are only a tiny part of creating a successful whole product.

pubs.title: Design Methods
pubs.contribution: An online, self-published book that surveys HCI and Design methods in a simple, accessible, and direct manner.

pubs.title: Principles of a Debugging-First Puzzle Game for Computing Education
pubs.contribution: Teaching debugging first, while redirecting blame to the computer instead of the learner, can increase learning efficiency and engage learners of all genders equally.

pubs.title: Thirty Years of Software Problems in the News
pubs.source: International Workshop on Cooperative and Human Aspects of Software Engineering (CHASE)
pubs.contribution: Software failures reported in the news describe mostly minor consequences, though reports of death, injury, or loss of access to basic needs is increasing.

pubs.title: Challenging Stereotypes and Changing Attitudes: The Effect of a Brief Programming Encounter on Adults' Attitudes toward Programming
pubs.source: ACM Symposium on Computer Science Education
pubs.contribution: Adult attitudes toward programming, while generally negative, can be quickly turned positive with a brief exposure to a debugging game.

pubs.title: A Practical Guide to Controlled Experiments of Software Engineering Tools with Human Participants
pubs.contribution: Software engineering researchers rarely evaluate new tools with software developers, but there are several best practices that can make such evaluations less risky and difficult to conduct.

pubs.title: Interactive Record/Replay for Web Application Debugging
pubs.contribution: A system for recording inputs to a web application and replaying them deterministically with minimal time or space overhead.

pubs.title: In-Game Assessments Increase Novice Programmers' Engagement and Learning Efficiency
pubs.contribution: Including brief assessments in a programming game improves engagement and learning efficiency.

pubs.title: A Multi-Site Field Study of Crowdsourced Contextual Help: Usage and Perspectives of End-Users and Software Teams
pubs.contribution: Contextual help is well-liked by both end-users and software teams in real world use.

pubs.title: Crowdsourced Q&A-based Contextual Help for Web Applications: Challenges and Opportunities
pubs.source: CSCW Workshop on Social Media Question Asking
pubs.contribution: Summarizes preliminary work on the LemonAid prototype.

pubs.title: LemonAid: Selection-Based Crowdsourced Contextual Help for Web Applications
pubs.contribution: A technique for extracting queries from selections of user interface elements that provides reliable, relevant help retrieval.

pubs.title: Is This What You Meant? Promoting Listening on the Web with Reflect
pubs.contribution: A technique for demonstrating listening on the web through restatement that engages lurkers in supporting common ground in groups.

pubs.title: Mining Whining in Support Forums with Frictionary
pubs.source: ACM Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI), alt.chi
pubs.contribution: A technique for extracting aggregate patterns in software problems by analyzing the natural language text of technical support discussion forums.

pubs.title: Designing for a Billion Users: A Case Study of Facebook
pubs.source: ACM Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems, Case Studies (CHI)
pubs.contribution: Efforts to make a universal product can limit innovation, both because of the diversity of user knowledge and the limits of interpreting data science patterns.

pubs.title: Personifying Programming Tool Feedback Improves Novice Programmers' Learning
pubs.contribution: Giving a computer eyes and having it use personal pronouns that double the amount of time that learners engaging in discretionary computing education by focusing their attention on instructional material.

pubs.title: Feedlack Detects Missing Feedback in Web Applications
pubs.contribution: A static program analysis for finding all inputs in a user interface that do not produce some form of feedback.

pubs.title: Characterizing the Differences Between Pre- and Post- release Versions of Software
pubs.contribution: Beta-testers use more applications, engage in more self-install, come from non-representative countries, and use more advanced hardware, skewing data on crashes, hangs, and kernel panics that is used for bug triage.

pubs.title: Design, Discussion, and Dissent in Open Bug Reports
pubs.contribution: Developers in open source can be passionate about making decisions that positively impact users, but often lack the information necessary to do this objectively, instead relying on anecdote, speculation, and hyperbole.

pubs.title: Gestalt: Integrated Support for Implementation and Analysis in Machine Learning Processes
pubs.contribution: A development environment that supports the translation of data into machine learned classifier  that improves the ability of developers to find and fix defects.

pubs.title: Cleanroom: Edit-Time Error Detection with the Uniqueness Heuristic
pubs.contribution: Detecting and highlighting identifiers that only appear once in dynamic languages helps developers find and fix challenging defects more quickly.

pubs.title: How Power Users Help and Hinder Open Bug Reporting
pubs.contribution: Most bug reports submitted from non-core open source contributors describe non-issues that devolve into technical support, providing little valuable information to the core community.

pubs.title: Understanding Usability Practices in Complex Domains: Implications for Training the Next Generation of Usability Professionals
pubs.contribution: Lack of domain expertise can be a significant hurdle for conducting effective user research and usability testing.

pubs.title: Attitudes and Self-Efficacy in Young Adults' Computing Autobiographies
pubs.contribution: First encounters with code must be accessible, error-tolerant and socially engaging, and must occur repeatedly across a lifetime to lead to deeper investment in computing education.

pubs.title: Finding Causes of Program Output with the Java Whyline
pubs.contribution: A user interface for debugging that supports why and why not questions that enables developers to localize faults significantly faster than breakpoint debuggers.

pubs.title: Fixing the Program My Computer Learned: Barriers for End Users, Challenges for the Machine
pubs.source: International Conference on Intelligent User Interfaces (IUI)
pubs.contribution: Enabling end users to debug machined learned programs by asking why questions about classifications causes end-users to locally optimize one class at the expense of other classes.

pubs.title: How Designers Design and Program Interactive Behaviors
pubs.contribution: Designers report that behavior is much more difficult to define than appearance, that it requires collaborating with developers, and that communicating behavior to developers is of particular difficulty.

pubs.title: Debugging Reinvented: Asking and Answering Why and Why Not Questions about Program Behavior
pubs.contribution: Static and dynamic program slicing algorithms for extracting and answering developers questions about program output that substantially decrease fault localization time.

pubs.title: Information Needs in Collocated Software Development Teams
pubs.contribution: Developers have many distinct information needs to be productive; some are frequent and well-served, such as information about changes to artifacts and coworker progress, but others are infrequent but critical, such as information about requirements, design rationale, and reproduction steps.

pubs.title: Let's Go to the Whiteboard: How and Why Software Developers Draw Code
pubs.contribution: Most of the diagrams that software developers make are transient and facilitate interpersonal communication and decision making and not for specifying or documenting program behavior.

pubs.title: A Linguistic Analysis of How People Describe Software Problems in Bug Reports
pubs.contribution: There is regularity in the grammar of bug report titles, suggesting the potential for applying natural language processing to searching, filtering, mining, and aggregating bug reports.

pubs.title: Answering Why and Why Not Questions in User Interfaces
pubs.contribution: Algorithms and user interfaces that allow end users to ask 'why' questions about unexpected application behavior.

pubs.title: Barista: An Implementation Framework for Enabling New Tools, Interaction Techniques and Views for Code Editors
pubs.contribution: Abstractions that make it easy to build rich multimedia interfaces in a code editor without sacrificing the ability to write code as text.

pubs.title: Citrus: A Language and Toolkit for Simplifying the Creation of Structured Editors for Code and Data
pubs.contribution: A programming language and library with language-level support for constraints, restrictions and change notifications on primitive and aggregate data.

pubs.title: Examining Task Engagement in Sensor-Based Statistical Models of Human Interruptibility
pubs.contribution: Developers' interruptibility can be predicted with high certainty by observing and classifying features of programming activity.

pubs.title: Eliciting Design Requirements for Maintenance-Oriented IDEs: A Detailed Study of Corrective and Perfective Maintenance Tasks
pubs.contribution: When developers fix a big or enhance a feature, they find a set of task-relevant code fragments and navigate dependencies between these fragments, but spend up to 35% of their time simply operating navigational controls in IDEs.

pubs.title: Six Learning Barriers in End-User Programming Systems
pubs.contribution: When people write programs, they face at least six distinct problems: 1) identifying a solution, 2) finding abstractions to implement the solution, 3) coordinating these abstractions, 4) properly configuring these abstractions, 5) identifying possible causes of program failures, and 6) getting information about program execution.

pubs.title: Designing the Whyline: A Debugging Interface for Asking Questions About Program Failures
pubs.contribution: Algorithms and user interfaces for extracting and answering why and why not questions about program behavior.

pubs.title: Development and Evaluation of a Model of Programming Errors
pubs.contribution: Software defects are caused by cognitive breakdowns in specification, implementation and debugging activities and analysis of these breakdowns can be used to identify tools that prevent these breakdowns.

pubs.title: Individual Differences in Program Comprehension Strategies in Unfamiliar Environments
pubs.source: IEEE International Workshop on Program Comprehension (IWPC)
pubs.contribution: Programming expertise shapes strategy, but domain expertise is a better predictor of bug fixing success than strategy.

pubs.title: Visually Testing Recursive Programs in Spreadsheet Languages
pubs.source: IEEE Symposia on Human-Centric Computing Languages and Environments
pubs.contribution: Two technique for testing recursive spreadsheets, neither of which can be understood by spreadsheet users.

pubs.title: Using the Cognitive Walkthrough to Improve the Design of a Visual Programming Experiment
pubs.contribution: An adaptation of the cognitive walkthrough technique that helps identify uncontrolled source of variations in experiments on developers tools.

pubs.title: Why-Oriented End-User Debugging of Naive Bayes Text Classification
pubs.source: ACM Transactions on Interactive Intelligent Systems, 1(1), Article 2
pubs.contribution: A technique that allows end-users to debug the underlying logic of machine learned classifiers.

pubs.title: The State of the Art in End-User Software Engineering
pubs.contribution: Defines end-user programming and end-user software engineering, then presents the extensive history of efforts to integrate software engineering activities into programming environments.

pubs.title: Extracting and Answering Why and Why Not Questions about Java Program Output
pubs.source: ACM Transactions on Software Engineering and Methodology, 22(2)
pubs.contribution: An application of static and dynamic program slicing, precise call graphs, reachability analyses, and value provenance that enables developers to localize faults through why and why not questions.

pubs.title: An Exploratory Study of How Developers Seek, Relate, and Collect Relevant Information during Software Maintenance Tasks
pubs.contribution: Developers work on software maintenance tasks by searching for relevant code, navigating dependencies, and constructing a mental model of the dependencies of a feature, suggesting the need for environments that explicitly support feature location through dependency navigation.

pubs.title: A Framework and Methodology for Studying the Causes of Software Errors in Programming Systems
pubs.source: Journal of Visual Languages and Computing
pubs.contribution: Software defects arise from latent errors in specifications, developer knowledge, tool support, and program implementation, ultimately producing runtime failures.

pubs.title: Improving the Design of Visual Programming Language Experiments Using Cognitive Walkthroughs
pubs.source: Journal of Visual Languages and Computing, 13(5)
pubs.contribution: An adaption of the cognitive walkthrough for finding potential difficulties of novice users in an evaluation of a developer tool.

pubs.title: The Role of Conceptual Knowledge in API Usability
pubs.contribution: Test the feasibility of a feature in an API requires architectural and terminology knowledge of the API, which is often missing from documentation.

pubs.title: Post-Deployment Usability: A Survey of Current Practices
pubs.contribution: Technical support and design are rarely linked in software companies despite significant opportunities for user research, usability feedback, and feature ideas.

pubs.title: Understanding Expressions of Unwanted Behaviors in Open Bug Reporting
pubs.contribution: The more a bug reporter expresses the issue in terms of a violation of community expectations of program behavior rather than individual expectations, the more likely it is to be fixed.

pubs.title: The Past, Present and Future of Programming in HCI
pubs.contribution: Summarizes past work on programming interfaces and open challenges in supporting the broader set of programming activities.

pubs.title: Dimensions Characterizing Programming Feature Usage by Information Workers
pubs.contribution: End user programmers use of programming is typically limited to one of three language features: macros for automation, linked structure queries, or imperative features.

pubs.title: Debugging by Asking Questions About Program Output
pubs.contribution: A doctoral consortium abstract, summarizing progress on the Whyline for Java.

pubs.title: Invited Research Overview: End-User Programming
pubs.contribution: A brief summary of the research area of end-user programming.

pubs.title: Using Objects of Measurement to Detect Spreadsheet Errors
pubs.contribution: A language feature for specifying the unit of analysis for values in a spreadsheet, allowing the language to identify type errors as unit of analysis mismatch.

pubs.title: Design Requirements for More Flexible Structured Editors from a Study of Programmers' Text Editing
pubs.contribution: When writing code in a text editor, developers regularly pass through invalid syntactic states, making strict structured editors infeasible.

pubs.title: Designing a Flexible and Supportive Direct-Manipulation Programming Environment
pubs.contribution: Finds that structured editors need some room for passing between unstructured phases to flexibly support editing.

pubs.title: Preserving Non-Programmers Motivation with Error-Prevention and Debugging Support Tools
pubs.source: IEEE Symposia Human-Centric Computing Languages and Environments
pubs.contribution: Summarizes Amy's early thoughts on her dissertation work.

pubs.title: A Contextual Inquiry of Expert Programmers in an Event-Based Programming Environment
pubs.contribution: Summarizes preliminary insights on debugging, showing that end-user programmers often start from faulty assumptions about runtime behavior.

pubs.title: Representations of User Feedback in an Agile, Collocated Software Team
pubs.source: International Workshop on Cooperative and Human Aspects of Software Engineering (CHASE)
pubs.contribution: As issues reported by end users are transformed from emails, to support ticket, to discussion, to bug report, to feature specification, information from the original request is lost, but remains in the distributed memory of the team.

pubs.title: A Case Study of Post-Deployment User Feedback Triage
pubs.source: International Workshop on Cooperative and Human Aspects of Software Engineering (CHASE)
pubs.contribution: User feedback is often ignored in because software teams perceive most feedback as minority opinion that conflicts with prior architectural decisions.

pubs.title: Comparing Bioinformatics Software Development by Computer Scientists and Biologists: An Exploratory Study
pubs.source: Workshop on Software Engineering for Computational Science and Engineering
pubs.contribution: Colleagues play a significant role in information seeking activities by developers in bioinformatics because of the high demand for domain knowledge.

pubs.title: JASPER: An Eclipse Plug-In to Facilitate Software Maintenance Tasks
pubs.source: Proceedings of the 2006 OOPSLA Workshop on Eclipse Technology eXchange
pubs.contribution: A tool for organizing related code fragments during software maintenance tasks.

pubs.title: Supporting Active Listening and Grounding on the Web through Restatement
pubs.source: ACM Conference on Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW), Horizons Workshop
pubs.contribution: Shares preliminary work on a vision for an internet that incentivizes listening.

pubs.title: Designing Crowdsourced, Context-Sensitive Help for Web Applications
pubs.source: Workshop on Crowdsourcing and Human Computation
pubs.contribution: Summarizes progress on the LemonAid help system.

pubs.title: How Do Open Source Developers Talk about Users?
pubs.source: CHI 2010 Workshop on The Future of FLOSS in CHI Research and Practice
pubs.contribution: Shows that many open source developers speak in generalities about users and their needs, leaning on stereotypes and instinct instead of evidence.

pubs.title: Designing Software for Unfamiliar Domains
pubs.source: Workshop on Cooperative and Human Aspects of Software Engineering (CHASE)
pubs.contribution: A brief abstract summarizing progress on how designers work with domain experts, finding that learning about a domain is the biggest challenge.

pubs.title: Source-Level Debugging with the Whyline
pubs.source: Workshop on Cooperative and Human Aspects of Software Engineering
pubs.contribution: Describes a pilot study of the Whyline for Java, showing that users were twice as fast at fixing a particular defect than without the Whyline.

pubs.title: Human Factors Affecting Dependability in End-User Programming
pubs.contribution: Enumerates many cognitive biases that shape the mistake that people make when engaging in end user programming.

pubs.title: End-User Programming Productivity Tools
pubs.contribution: Shares examples of research from the Natural Programming project.

pubs.title: More Natural End-User Software Engineering
pubs.source: International Workshop on End-User Software Engineering
pubs.contribution: Shares recent progress on the Natural Programming project.

pubs.title: More Natural and Open User Interface Tools
pubs.source: Workshop on the Future of User Interface Design Tools
pubs.contribution: A 2 page abstract on progress on Brad Myer's Natural Programming project.

pubs.title: The Role of Science in Supporting Software Development
pubs.source: Workshop on Supporting the Social Side of Large-Scale Software Development, at the 2006 ACM Conference on Computer Supported Cooperative Work
pubs.contribution: Argues that progress on inventions requires scientific, theoretical explanations of their value.

pubs.title: Software Engineering Through Qualitative Methods
pubs.source: Making Software: What Really Works, and Why We Believe It
pubs.contribution: Argues that qualitative methods are essential for understanding the dynamics of software engineering teamwork.

pubs.title: New to the Movement: Reflections on the Future of Information Schools from Inspired Junior Faculty
pubs.contribution: Presents a unification of information science and human-computer interaction concerns.

pubs.title: Natural Programming Languages and Environments
pubs.contribution: Describes the Natural Programming project, which sought to make it possible for people to express their ideas in the same way they think about them.

pubs.title: Identifying Types of End Users: Hints from an Informal Survey
pubs.source: Carnegie Mellon University ISRI Technical Report, no. CMU-HCII-05-101 and Human Computer Interaction Institute Technical Report, no CMU-ISRI-05-110
pubs.contribution: Presents a clustering of end user programming activities, finding revealing variation in advanced feature usage.

pubs.title: Investigating the Role of Purposeful Goals on Novices' Engagement in a Programming Game
pubs.contribution: Representing data as animate, vertebrate objects instead of abstract, inanimate objects greatly increases engagement in online coding tutorials.

pubs.title: Individual Differences in Programming, Testing, and Debugging Strategies in a Statistical End-User Programming Environment
pubs.contribution: Programming expertise shapes strategy, but domain expertise is a better predictor of bug fixing success than strategy

pubs.title: Asking and Answering Questions about the Causes of Software Behaivors
pubs.contribution: Proposes the Java Whyline.

pubs.title: Asking and Answering Questions about the Causes of Software Behavior
pubs.contribution: Describes the discoveries of several investigations into debugging and presents the concept, implementation, and evaluation of interrogtative debugging, and the several prototypes that embody it, including the Whyline for Alice, the Whyline for Java, and Crystal.

people.name: Amy J. Ko
people.bio: Amy is the director of the lab.

projects.name: Justice-focused computing education
projects.description: Computing is powerful, but that power is often used by dominant groups in ways that disregard, exclude, or even harm marginalized groups, amplifying and reinforcing sexist, racist, and ableist structures and ideas. My lab is exploring teaching methods, learning technologies, and teacher education paradigms that center these power dynamics in CS education.

projects.name: Broadening participation in computing
projects.description: The world is full of structural barriers to developing interest in and learning computing. My lab investigates these barriers and ways to eradicate them, including issues around accessibility, mentorship, culture, identity, and resources, with the goal of increasing the diversity of people in computing disciplines.

projects.name: Understanding machine learning
projects.description: While most programs are still written by developers, many are now built by gathering large amounts of data and automatically creating machine learned programs. My lab is investigating the immense comprehension challenges imposed by these probablistic forms of program behavior, as well as the literacy required to understand how they are shaping program behavior and society.

projects.name: Programming language learning
projects.description: Robust understanding of a programming language is a key foundation for being able to create software. My lab investigates what it means to know a programming language, invents and evaluates educational technologies that streamline learning of a programming language, and invents and evaluates assessments that help identify what learners do and do not know about a programming language.

projects.name: Programming problem solving
projects.description: A critical part of creating software is being able to understand programming problems, identify solutions to solve them, and systematically implement, verify, and debug programs, and avoid mistakes throughout. My lab investigates effective ways of learning these skills, and orchestrating them with self-regulation, process, and strategy.

projects.name: API learning
projects.description: Most modern software is built by reusing APIs, libraries, frameworks, and other code that others have carefully designed and tested. Unfortunately, such reuse often requires robust learning of API features. My lab investigates barriers to learning API's robustly and invents more effective ways of learning APIs.

projects.name: Software engineering expertise
projects.description: Engineering production software requires far more than knowing how to code. We've investigated the skills that are required for developers to be great engineers, including not only technical skills, but communication, collaboration, design, and business skills as well.

projects.name: User interface mining
projects.description: User interfaces are structured documents, allowing us to analyze, reverse engineer, and transform them. My lab is applying techniques from program analysis and synthesis to automatically transform interfaces to be more accessible, usable, and useful.

projects.name: Theory and methods
projects.description: Studying programming is hard. We invent new methods for studying programming, and reflect on the science of studying programming, to help accelerate progress on improving it.

projects.name: Literature reviews and surveys
projects.description: A critical part of scholarly progress is synthesizing and explaining what we've learned. Sometimes this results in robust discussions of prior work; other times we go further, publishing standalone papers and book chapters that help newcomers make sense of what we know.

projects.name: Understanding program behavior
projects.description: Finding and fixing bugs is challenging. My lab studies debugging and invents tools that it make program understanding easier by combining human intelligence with machine intelligence.

projects.name: Bug triage and user feedback
projects.description: When software gets shared with the world, helping people use it, and understanding their struggles in using it, are critical to improving it. My lab has studied challenges in gathering user feedback, and invented several tools that both provide better technical support, while also gathering data to improve software.

projects.name: End-user software engineering
projects.description: Many people write code to support their own work (e.g., teachers write grading spreadsheets, scientists write scripts to process data, people automate their homes). In these end-user programming contexts, people face many of the same challenges that arise in professional software engineering, just without the same incentives to be systematic in testing, debugging, and maintenance. Our work has investigated these contexts and invented tools to support them.

impacts.description: Our research on Lemonaid, our crowdsourced help tool, was the basis for AnswerDash, a company that I co-founded with Jacob Wobbrock and Parmit Chilana that offers an instant self-service answers product for web applications and e-commerce sites. The company has impacted other company's product offerings, including Zendesk's self-service technologies. AnswerDash was acquired in 2020 by CloudEngage, a platform for customer personalization
Our research on bug reporting has been read widely in industry, including by product teams at Microsoft, Adobe, Google, and ABB
PC Magazine featured my research on the Whyline debugging tool
impacts.title: The Ten Biggest Problems in Computing and How We'll Solve Them
impacts.author: Alan Cohen

impacts.description: I was interviewed by Jeff Meyerson for the Software Engineering Daily podcast on February 24 about research, reaching tens of thousands of engineers
impacts.title: Academia to Industry in Computer Science
impacts.author: Jeff Meyerson

impacts.description: Our ACM Learning Webinar on software engineering expertise was viewed by hundreds of thousands of developers
Our research on software engineering expertise was read by tens of thousands of software developers on Hacker News
Our research on coding bootcamps has been read by tens of thousands of software developers on Hacker News
Our research on coding tutorials read by tens of thousands of software developers on Hacker News
Our work on end-user software engineering has inspired hundreds of commercial tools for supporting end-user programming and impacted research efforts in professional software engineering
Our work on understanding machine learning has indirectly shaped several of the tools used in industry to develop and debug machine learned programs
Our work on interface mining has been replicated in several industry projects focused on supporting interface development
Our studies on program understanding and ideas for program understanding tools was partially the basis of the Debugger Canvas plugin for Visual Studio
Frictionary was used in one of the features in AnswerDash, the company I co-founded based on my CAREER grant

Portions of Timelapse and Scry were upstreamed to WebKit and may eventually appear in the Safari Web Inspector developer tools. These projects inspired similar features at the venture-backed startup replay.io.
My work on Barista influenced the Greenfoot editor
Our work on PL Tutor influenced the JustJavaScript course by Dan Abramov
I consulted with Microsoft's VS Code, VS Online, and GitHub Education teams about how to support CS educators
I consulted with Microsoft on their project, sharing evidence from computing education research to inform the design of their learning technologies
Gidget has been played by tens of thousans of youth adults online, in summer camps, and in high schools
Codeitz, our Python tutorial which incoporates our theory of programming instruction, is publicly available, and used to support Python instruction
We influenced the teaching of HCI education in higher education
I write and share online books that summarize the state of knowledge in HCI and Software Engineering
I shared my practices and experiences with productivity and time management in the Changing Academic Life podcast
I share thoughts on academia and academic life on my blog, read by tens of thousands
Our work has opened discourse on the responsibility of CS educators to address the role of CS in injustice
Our work on research methods is widely read by new Ph.D. students across computer science to inform how they evaluate new developer tools and how they use theory

Greg Nelson's arguments about the role of theory in computing education research have spurred signfiicant debate in CS education. This debate was continued in a 60 minute panel session at ICER 2018 in Finland, an then another 90 minute panel session at SIGCSE in Minneapolis
Our surveys are widely-cited and used by doctoral students to quickly learn about the state of the art and knowledge
I consulted with Google, NSF, CRA, and Code.org on strategies for strengthening the pipeline of computing education research, researchers, and research funding
Co-authored a whitepaper discussing the importance of computing education research
Since 2016 I've maintained a popular FAQ for newcomers to the community
I've helped shape the peer review processes for the ACM Transactions on Computing Education journal
I've helped shape the reviewing criteria for the ACM SIGCSE Technical Symposium's research track
I've heleped shape the peer review process for ACM International Computing Education Research Conference
I write blog posts on about computing education research topics are read widely amongst researchers and CS teachers
Our work on assessment has imported more rigorous methods from educational measurement into CS education
I was interviewed by Jared O'Leary on their BootUP CS podcast, where I talked about reflection, mentorship, and vulnerability.
impacts.title: Vulnerability, Reflection, and CS Education with Amy Ko
impacts.author: Jared O'Leary

impacts.description: I've coordinated with House representatives on policies that will expand the numbers of CS teachers nationwide

Our research on programming problem solving, programming language learning, programming strategies, and debugging has shaped Code.org's teacher professional development and it's secondary school curricula, impacting hundreds of thousands of U.S. youth
Our research on software engineering expertise informed the curriculum at New York's Academy for Software Engineering
Gidget influenced the design of Code.org's Code Studio
Gidget influenced the design of Apple's Swift Playgrounds
Gidget has been played by tens of thousands of youth adults online, in summer camps, and in high schools
The CS for All Washington advocacy group I direct has used our research to affect statewide CS education policy
Our research on transfer students has influenced admissions policy at the University of Washington

As part of our research, we have taught in the University of Washington's Upward Bound program each summer, reaching dozens of students underrepresented in computing from Seattle's low-income immigrant and refugee communities
I've run a quarterly meetup, Sound CS Ed, to bring together hundreds of CS education teachers, researchers, policy makers, and product designers in Puget Sound
I have served on the Seattle Public Schools CS Advisory board, shaping strategic goals

talks.alt: The title slide, which says 'Programming as cognition, programming as politics'.
talks.title: Programming as Cognition, Programming as Politics
talks.venue: University of Colorado Boulder, Institute for Cognitive Science
talks.description: In this talk, I survey my 20 years of research on programming, some of which has framed it as a distributed sociocognitive activity, and some of which has framed it as a political activity. I reconcile these two perspectives by rejecting the dichotomy, and advocating for work that considers them in tandem.

talks.alt: The title slide, which says 'Code, Calculators, Creativity, and the Many Paths to CS Education' and shows a TI-82 graphing calculator.
talks.title: Code, Calculators, Creativity, and the Many Paths to CS Education
talks.description: In this short keynote, I shared my path to computing and then make the case for many paths to computing through student interests.

talks.alt: The title slide, which says 'Requirements of Oppression' and shows a Banksy piece with a small girl strip searching a soldier.
talks.title: Requirements of Oppression
talks.description: This keynote argues that requirements are the central way that software models the matrix of oppression, and that to be anti-oppressive, requirements engineering must center the margins, humanity, and activism in its work.

talks.alt: The title slide, which says 'The Roots of Inequity in K-12 CS Education' and shows an elementary CS classroom.
talks.title: The Roots of Inequity in K-12 CS Education
talks.description: This is a keynote I gave the CS Teachers Association (CSTA) annual conference. It discusses the many interacting layers of inequity in K-12 CS education, including many of my own personal experiences discovering inequities in schools that I or others have created. It also offers suggestions to teachers about how they can participate in identifying and dismantling barriers.

talks.alt: A slide, which says 'Deconstructing CS Culture' and shows Amy's title, along with an illustration of people climbing on a tower of binary digits.
talks.title: Deconstructing CS Culture
talks.description: This talk examined the hidden marginalization that led to the CS culture we have today, discussing CS history, Autism, immigration, queer refuges, segregation, desegregation, capitalism, and more.

talks.alt: A slide, which says 'Recognize your power and the responsibility that comes with it.
talks.title: Critical Computing Education
talks.venue: Digital Learning Lab, University of California, Irvine
talks.description: This was the seventh time I gave my talk on critical computing education. In this version, I revised the slides to speak more to a learning sciences and education audience.

talks.alt: A slide, which says 'Computing has limits', and includes an xkcd coment that says 'An analysis of our new AI hiring algorithm has raised some concerns'
talks.title: Critical Computing Education
talks.venue: California Institute of Technology, Computing and Mathematical Sciences, Keller Colloquium
talks.description: This was the sixth time I gave my talk on critical computing education. In this version, I updated the research slides with new papers and evidence.

talks.alt: The closing slide of the talk: 1) computing has limits, 2) data has limits, 3) CS has responsibility, and a column of doctoral student headshots and names.
talks.title: Critical Computing Education
talks.venue: University of California, Davis, Computer Science, Computing Education Research at Davis Seminar
talks.description: This was the fifth time I gave my talk on critical computing education. In this version, I updated the research slides with new papers and evidence.

talks.alt: A photograph of me taking a selife with my virtual audience.

talks.description: This was the fourth time I gave my Autumn 2020 talk on critical computing education. In this version, I selected examples more situated in Philadelphia's history.

talks.alt: The first slide of my talk, showing the title Computing Education: A Critical Time for a Critical Literacy
talks.title: Computing Education: A Critical Time for a Critical Literacy
talks.description: I was invited to give a short keynote at the IT University of Copenhagen's inauguration of Center for Computing Education Research (CCER). Michael Caspersen and Simon Peyton Jones also spoke.

talks.alt: A photograph of my speaker setup, showing my first slide and my hoisted iPad showing the audience.
talks.title: Critical Computing Education
talks.venue: Carnegie Mellon University, HCI Institute, Seminar Series
talks.description: This was the third time I gave my Autumn 2020 talk on critical computing education. In this version, I linked my framing to my time as a graduate student at Carnegie Mellon.

talks.alt: The first slide of the talk showing the title Critical Computing Education and a photo of Black Lives Matter protests.
talks.title: Critical Computing Education
talks.venue: University of Virginia, Computer Science Distinguished Speaker Series
talks.description: This was the second time I gave my Autumn 2020 talk on critical computing education. In this version, I expanded discussion of my lab's research and strengthened the call to action.

talks.alt: A screenshot of the end of my talk, showing questions, a summary of the talk gist, and several faces on Zoom.
talks.title: Critical Computing Education
talks.venue: University of Colorado joint Colloqium of the Department of Information Science and College of Media, Communication and Information
talks.description: This was the first in a series of talks about my research pivot on critical computing education. In it, I argue for the need for universal literacy about the limits of computing, the limits of data, and the responsibilty of computer science to teach these limits. I shared recent examples of research from our lab that's beginning to explore how to teach these limits.

talks.alt: A screenshot of the first slide of the presentation, with the title Studying Programming through Making
talks.title: Studying Programming through Making
talks.description: I gave this invited presentation on August 3rd, to at the 2020 PL+HCI "Swimmer School". The overarching goal was to explain how user studies shape our understanding of what we make; it also served as a retrospective of my dissertation work on the Whyline.

talks.alt: A photograph of students on the campus of Howard University, 1870
talks.title: CS Education in Higher Education
talks.description: I gave this presentation to Microsoft on June 15th; they were engaging in design envisioning to support CS teaching and wanted some background on it and how the pandemic was affecting it. I used it as an opportunity to talk about the racist and sexist history of higher education, of CS in higher education, the ways that CS pedagogy have failed to include all students, and how the pandemic has amplified these failures. I shared it on Twitter, which led to considerable sharing, solidatory, and outrage. I intentionally did not include citations for my claims because scientific evidence tends to be weaponized by those do not believe that racism or sexism exists; instead, I included a link pointing to the body of literature supporting the claims.

talks.alt: A screenshot of the first slide of the keynote, showing title and Koli national park.
talks.title: 21st Century Grand Challenges in Computing Education
talks.venue: 2019 Koli Calling Computing Education Research Conference
talks.description: I gave this keynote at the 2019 Koli Calling conference, a computing education research conference in beautiful Koli National Park. In it, I argued that to address epistemic challenges such as climate change and stabilizing democracies, everyone in the world needs to learn the limits of computing, social responsibility with computing, data literacy, and diversity literacy.

talks.alt: A screenshot of the first slide of the keynote.
talks.title: Programming: What it is and How to Teach it
talks.description: I gave this invited talk in 2019 at ETH Zurich's CS department. I shared my lab's latest research on programming, including programming language learning, API learning, programming problem solving, and programming strategies.

talks.alt: A screenshot of the first slide of the talk.
talks.title: Big Ideas Behind the Whyline
talks.description: I gave this talk in 2018 in recognition for my most influential paper award on my dissertation work on the Whyline. I reflected on the ideas, both technical, scientific, and otherwise that have shaped my discoveries.

talks.alt: A screenshot of the first slide of the keynote.
talks.title: Mining the Mind, Minding the Mine: Grand Challenges in Comprehension and Mining
talks.venue: 2018 International Conference on Mining Software Repositories and International Conference on Program Comprehension
talks.description: I gave this invited joint keynote at the 2018 International Conference on Mining Software Repositories, and the International Conference on Program Comprehension. I argued that the two areas need each other, that they both need theory, and that they both need to ask more relevant questions.

classes.alt: A black and white version of an old painting with a child reading a newspaper
classes.title: Intellectual Foundations of Informatics
classes.description: This survey course covers big ideas in information, information technology, and information systems. Students learn the history of information, foundational concepts in information, the relationship between information and computing, skills in analyzing and designing information systems, and the role of information systems in society.

links.description: Medium post on the big ideas in the course

classes.alt: A line drawing of two people discussing a sketch
classes.title: Design Methods
classes.description: This undergraduate class teaches students design thinking skills in the domain of information and computing. It leverages multiple forms of active learning, involves a significant amount of studio-based learning, and helps students develop creative confidence.

links.description: Amy's online book for the course

classes.alt: A photograph of Margaret Hamilton standing next to source code.
classes.title: Cooperative Software Development
classes.description: This undergraduate software engineering class teaches foundations of team-based software development, leveraging the latest research on coordination, cooperation, and human cognition in software development. Students leave ready to become meaningful contributors to teams big and small, but also to understand the processes that teams use and how they can improve them.

links.description: Amy's online book for the course

classes.alt: A photograph of students at the capstone fair.
classes.title: Capstone
classes.description: This undergraduate capstone sequence engages students in a 6-month project, usually culminating in a functional, deployable prototype, and often in collaboration with a client from local industry.

classes.alt: A black and white photograph of a woman operating the ENIAC, the first computer
classes.title: User Interface Software and Technology
classes.description: This core course in our Masters of HCI+Design teaches students they history, theory, and foundations of user interfaces. Students acquire a literacy for communicating and reasoning about interfaces.

links.description: Amy's online book for the course

classes.alt: A photograph of the 2011 class amidst discussion.
classes.title: HCI Design Foundations for Interactive Systems
classes.description: This doctoral course teaches theoretical foundations of HCI, preparing students as designers, design researchers, and HCI researchers.

classes.title: Computer Science Equity & Justice
classes.description: This graduate course educates teacher candidates about equity and justice issues in computer science and computer science education, while also teaching content knowledge foundations of CS. I teach it in partnership with the UW College of Education's Secondary Teacher Education Program, which I'm helping design and launch.

commitments.title: Advising
commitments.description: Doctoral student meetings, feedback, and collaboration

commitments.title: Book writing
commitments.description: Finishing a draft of a collaborative book.
